'Does anyone know the number of infected people there?' No, and we're not going to know the precise number unless a lot of money and time would be put to the task, which isn't likely to happen.It is a given that X people will have come in contact with nCoV and have had mild respiratory illnesses thereafter. Some of those people will think they had colds, others might have referred to it as flu, but they will have now recovered and not known they contracted nCoV.Unless antibody testing for those X people could be done then determining 'the number of infected people' won't be known as there are not the resources to go through the process.That a percentage of the X who've contracted nCoV will have had comorbidities that will have made them more susceptible to the pneumonia caused by nCoV is also a given, but some of those may not have sought medical attention but instead struggled through and have now recovered or have had an acute on chronic response to another comorbidity and nCoV identification may have gone by the wayside.Basic infection control advice holds: wash your hands frequently.
